title-group.article-title: Redistributive Impact of Indirect Tax Reforms: Greece, 1988–2002

abstract.p: This paper assesses the distributional impact of indirect taxes among Greek households between 1988 and 2002, a period that coincides with the introduction of significant reforms in the tax system due to EU membership. The highly differentiated indirect tax structure prevailing at the beginning of the period had distributional benefits over the more simplified 2002 tax structure. The overall inequality of the after-tax welfare distribution has increased by 6–12½ per cent and changes in the indirect tax system seem to explain about half of this increase. The paper also applies a recent method of measuring the distributional impact of relative price changes caused by changes in tax rates of commodities (Newbery, 1995) and establishes that indirect tax reforms introduced since 1988 had an adverse impact on the distribution of purchasing power, which nevertheless seems to be very small.

p.mixed-citation: Namely, stamp duties and the business turnover tax, which at the beginning of the 1980s yielded around 90 per cent of revenue from general sales taxes.

For the analysis of the 1988 tax system, the 1988 HES has been used, while for the analysis of the 2002 tax system, we have used the data from the most recent HES, conducted in 1999. This should provide a good description of expenditure patterns for 2002.

Various dimensions of the representativeness of the HES sample have been checked against macro-variables from other sources and results are quite satisfactory, thus guaranteeing the quality of results; see Kaplanoglou (1999) and Kaplanoglou and Newbery (2003a).
This has been recognised in several studies on inequality, poverty and tax incidence (for example, Blundell and Preston (1994 and 1995) and Goodman and Webb (1995)).
This view is defended and followed in a number of studies (for example, McGregor and Borooah (1992), Newbery (1995) and Newbery and Révész (2000)).

Deciles rank households according to equivalent non-durable expenditure and split the sample into 10 groups, so that decile 1 contains the 'poorest' 10 per cent of the sample and decile 10 contains the 'richest' 10 per cent of the sample.
For a detailed analysis of the distributional impact of the 1988 indirect tax system, see Kaplanoglou (2000).
Indirect taxes have been ranked in order of regressivity using Suits tax concentration curves. For a full exposition, see Kaplanoglou and Newbery (2003b).
Two other measures of road user charges gave essentially the same results.

The null hypothesis that mean expenditure is higher for households with cars than for households without cars could not be rejected at the 0.01 significance level for several different expenditure measures both in 1988 and in 2002.
This is due to the fact that between 1988 and 2002, car purchase taxes and transport dues significantly decreased and were made less progressive and the tax rate on motor fuel slightly decreased.

In the case of the uniform equal-yield tax and in the absence of detailed information on price elasticities, we implicitly assume own-price elasticities equal to -1 for all commodities and zero cross-price effects. In this way, the household budget constraint is not violated.
For details of the calculation of summary statistics and a review of the voluminous literature on the comparison and ranking of different distributions, see Cowell (1995).

To be consistent with the previous analysis, the distribution of expenditure is derived by assigning the value of expenditure per equivalent adult (using the OECD scale) to each equivalent adult in the household.
We also computed the effect of removing the road user charge element and found that the adverse changes were slightly reduced.

For all mean-independent inequality measures, such as the ones employed here, welfare distributions corresponding to no indirect taxes or to uniform indirect taxes are equivalent, if one makes the additional assumption that households will spend the same amount on commodities under prices corresponding to different tax regimes and will only adjust the quantity bought (this corresponds to own-price elasticities of demand equal to -1).
Optimal tax theory is set out in Diamond and Mirrlees (1971a and 1971b), Sandmo (1976), Atkinson and Stiglitz (1980), Auerbach (1985), Mirrlees (1986) and Ray (1997).
Similar rsults hold for 2002.

The 1988 budget shares and distributional characteristics have been used in the computation of results reported in Table 4, but results are remarkably similar if 2002 budget shares and distributional characteristics are used.
Another dimension along which we could judge the indirect tax system is efficiency. This aspect is explored in Kaplanoglou and Newbery (2003c).
Expenditure (rather than income) is the relevant argument in the individual's indirect utility function, given that we use expenditure as a welfare index (Slesnick, 1998).
